I've come against a small problem with the fitness sharing technique so 
I would like to ask how others are handling this...

I started by calculating the size of a species as follows:

   species.TotalAdjustedFitness / population.MeanAdjustedFitness

This I think will introduce a problem whereby the total size of the 
population will have a tendency to shrink or grow depending on whether 
you round the result of this expression up or down. ok  When I wrote the 
evolution algorithm last year I had though of this which is why I had 
chosen to cull the population as a whole back to it's proper size 
(instead of per species) which was not such a great idea :) Anyway the 
NEAT FAQ suggests using the following expression instead:

   species.MeanFitness / population.TotalOfSpeciesMeanFitness

Which is great except I just noticed that if all of the organisms have 
fitness 0 then I will end up with a population size of 0. I realise this 
is a special case, you would normaly see some minimal fitness in the 
initial population and hence no problem.

Possible solutions then.
1) Precalculate the size of the population, test for the zero case and 
if so then keep the original species sizes.
2) Define a minimum fitness greater than 0. This is a bit bit of a hack 
though really.
3) Keep generating initial populations until a none zero fitness occurs.

Thoughts?

Colin.
